population_specificity: In silico and molecular docking analysis (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of phytosterols as an alternative treatment for hypercholesterolemia in dogs by assessing their effects on lipid profiles and safety.
results_summary: Phytosterols significantly reduced LDL levels and increased HDL levels in healthy dogs without altering total cholesterol or triglyceride concentrations, suggesting potential efficacy for managing hypercholesterolemia. No adverse effects were reported during the trial.
population_specificity: Healthy Beagle dogs (n=8)
effective_dosage: 1300 mg daily (two 650 mg capsules), administered with meals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and analyze preclinical studies on the effects of phytosterols and phytostanols on cancer biology, focusing on mechanisms and outcomes.
results_summary: Phytosterols reduced primary and metastatic tumor burden across all evaluated cancer sites, decreased markers of metastasis, angiogenesis, and proliferation, but very high doses were linked to adverse events like poor gut health and intestinal adenoma development.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (in vitro and in vivo).
effective_dosage: Very high doses (0.2-1 g/kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-breast tumor effects of three phytosterols (DLA, DL, DP) from sweet potato in MCF-7 xenograft nude mice, focusing on tumor growth, serum markers, gut microbiota regulation, and cancer-related protein expression.
results_summary: DLA, DL, and DP delayed tumor growth, reduced tumor markers (CEA, CA125, CA153), modulated gut microbiota (increased Bacteroidetes, decreased Firmicutes), and influenced cancer-related protein expression (e.g., activated caspase 3/9, down-regulated Ki67/VEGF). DL and DP also promoted short-chain fatty acid secretion (butyric and acetic acid).
population_specificity: MCF-7 xenograft nude mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary phytosterols supplementation on growth performance and cecal gut microflora in yellow-feather broilers.
results_summary: Phytosterols at 25 mg/kg did not affect growth performance (feed intake, weight gain, food conversion rate) and had limited effects on gut microflora, reducing community richness but increasing Bacteroidetes abundance at the phylum level.
population_specificity: 1-day-old yellow-feather broilers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of six phytosterols on inhibiting the formation of thermally induced trans fatty acids (TFAs) in peanut oil.
results_summary: The study found that six phytosterols effectively inhibited the formation of trans oleic acid, trans linoleic acids, trans linolenic acids, and total TFAs in peanut oil. The anti-isomerization effects were linked to hydroxyl site activities, influenced by molecular structure features like double bond position and number.
population_specificity: Peanut oil, triolein, trilinolein, and trilinolenin (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of daily supplementation of 2 g of free-phytosterols nanoparticles in individuals with metabolic syndrome over six months compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterol supplementation significantly reduced the proportion of participants with high triglycerides (15.65% lower than placebo) and decreased waist circumference (up to 4 cm in half of the phytosterol group). No adverse effects were reported, and 70% of participants self-reported improved bowel habits.
population_specificity: 202 participants with metabolic syndrome (102 in the phytosterol group, 100 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD) enhances the biotransformation of soybean phytosterols into valuable steroid intermediates (AD and ADD) by Mycobacterium neoaurum.
results_summary: HP-β-CD improved phytosterol metabolism by enhancing steroid solubilization and altering cell wall permeability, mitigating the toxicity of AD and ADD on cell growth and electron transfer chains. Proteomic analysis revealed perturbations in steroid catabolism and glucose metabolism due to HP-β-CD treatment.
population_specificity: Mycobacterium neoaurum TCCC 11978 C2 (bacterial strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether phytosterols (PS) affect biomarkers of atherosclerosis progression independently of LDL-c reduction and to assess their impact on endothelial function.
results_summary: PS supplementation reduced endothelin-1 levels by 11% independently of LDL-c changes and lowered total cholesterol, LDL-c, triglycerides, and apo B, but did not affect HDL-c or other inflammatory biomarkers like IL-6, hs-CRP, or VCAM-1.
population_specificity: 38 moderately hypercholesterolemic volunteers (LDL-c ≥ 130 mg/dL), aged 58 ± 12 years.
effective_dosage: 1.6 g/day of PS in 400 mL/day of soy milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how incorporating phytosterols (β-sitosterol and stigmasterol) into mixed soy lecithin-based liposomes affects encapsulation efficiency, antioxidant capacity, and photothermal stability of quercetin-loaded liposomes.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols (βS and ST) enhanced encapsulation efficiency and antioxidant capacity (TEAC 197.23%) while reducing photodamage (TEAC loss 30.81% under UV exposure). Synergistic effects between phytosterols and quercetin improved membrane stability and liposome integrity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 0.15 g/100 mL β-sitosterol, 0.1 g/100 mL stigmasterol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the cholesterol-lowering and triglyceride-lowering mechanisms of phytosterols to improve hyperlipidemia and related diseases.
results_summary: Phytosterols effectively lower blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels by competitively inhibiting dietary cholesterol absorption and through other recently discovered mechanisms. Foods containing phytosterols are widely used as therapeutic diets for dyslipidemia.
population_specificity: Not specified (general hyperlipidemia population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of phytosterol supplementation on blood pressure through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 19 RCTs found that phytosterol supplementation significantly reduced both systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with dose-response and subgroup analyses indicating effectiveness at specific dosages and durations. The effect was more pronounced in subsets with shorter durations (<12 weeks) and varied by dosage (≥2000 mg for SBP, <2000 mg for DBP).
population_specificity: Hypertensive, prehypertensive, and normotensive individuals.
effective_dosage: ≥2000 mg/day for systolic BP, <2000 mg/day for diastolic BP.
study_duration: Subgroup analysis showed significant effects in durations <12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phytosterols modulate liver X receptor (LXR) activity in breast cancer cell lines and their potential role in altering cancer cell behavior.
results_summary: Phytosterols did not directly modulate LXR activity but significantly inhibited oxysterol-driven LXR transcription, suggesting a potential role in modulating cancer cell behavior via LXR pathways.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a phytosterols-enriched soya drink in lowering LDL-cholesterol levels and other cardiovascular parameters in normocholesterolaemic adults.
results_summary: The phytosterols-enriched soya drink significantly reduced LDL-cholesterol by 5.96% compared to baseline and 4.70% compared to placebo, with no significant changes in other lipid parameters, blood glucose, blood pressure, body weight, or waist circumference. Remarkably, 95% of participants reported no adverse events.
population_specificity: Normocholesterolaemic Chinese adults (85 men and 74 women; aged 19-79).
effective_dosage: 2 g of phytosterol per day (one serving of the enriched soya drink).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of phytosterol-fortified milk powder in reducing low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and cardiovascular risk in Malaysia.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterol-fortified milk powder was very cost-effective, potentially preventing thousands of myocardial infarctions and strokes, and saving healthcare costs. Sensitivity analyses supported the robustness of these findings.
population_specificity: 35-75-year-old population in Malaysia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess inter-individual variation in clinical biomarkers related to cardiometabolic risk in response to phytosterol consumption.
results_summary: The meta-analyses indicated that factors like age, sex, ethnicity, and health status contribute to variability in responsiveness to phytosterols, leading to inconsistent results across trials. The study highlighted the need for better reporting practices and further research on genetic and microbiome influences.
population_specificity: Varied populations including different ages, sexes, ethnicities, and pathophysiological statuses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the mechanism by which phytosterols restore metabolic homeostasis in the liver and colon in a dextran sulphate sodium-induced colitis model.
results_summary: Phytosterols reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, accelerated mucosal healing, and restored metabolic equilibrium in the liver and colon by modulating pathways like the Krebs cycle, carbohydrate, amino acid, and nucleotide metabolism.
population_specificity: Mice with dextran sulphate sodium-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of phytosterols (PS) and curcumin, administered via fortified bread, on plasma lipid profiles and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in hypercholesterolaemic individuals.
results_summary: The study found that PS-enriched bread significantly lowered total cholesterol (TC), LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C), and CVD risk compared to placebo, with reductions of 7.6% and 10.6% for TC and LDL-C, respectively. Curcumin alone did not influence blood lipids, and HDL-C and triglycerides remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolaemic individuals
effective_dosage: 2.3 g PS daily (with or without 228 mg curcumin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the stability and photooxidation kinetics of phytosterols in an oil matrix under varying light conditions and in the presence or absence of photosensitizers and unsaturated lipids.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols' photooxidation follows first-order kinetics, with higher light intensity and photosensitizers accelerating oxidation, while unsaturated lipids inhibited oxidation product formation. The main oxidation product was 7β-hydroxy, accounting for about one-third of total phytosterol oxides, with oxidation at C7 on the steroid nucleus being the primary pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using model matrix samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the binding tendency of Morinda lucida-derived phytosterols towards selected HDAC isoforms to identify potential natural HDAC inhibitors for anticancer therapeutics.
results_summary: The study found that three phytosterols (campesterol, cycloartenol, and stigmasterol) exhibited high HDAC inhibitory activity comparable to givinostat, fulfilled Lipinski's rule of five for oral drugability, and showed good binding affinity towards selected HDACs.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for simultaneously determining eight bioactive compounds, including phytosterols, in edible oils using optimized ultrasound-assisted saponification and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a method with high sensitivity (LOD 2.0–3.2 ng/mL) and accuracy (recoveries 81.7–112.0%), finding significantly higher levels of stigmasterol and other compounds in camellia oils compared to olive oils (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Edible oils (camellia and olive oils)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of plant and food-derived sterols and triterpenoids as hepatoprotective agents and their application in preventing and treating chronic liver diseases, cirrhosis, and HCC.
results_summary: The study found that sterols and triterpenoids exhibit antioxidant, metabolic-regulating, immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties, suggesting their potential as alternative therapies for liver diseases. Their structural similarity to cholesterol and related compounds allows them to share pharmacological properties by activating nuclear and membrane receptors.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of phytosterols and inulin on plasma glucose, insulin, and GLP-1 levels in healthy men after consuming enriched soymilk for 8 weeks.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in GLP-1 secretion (p=0.003) and a non-significant increase in insulin secretion (p=0.118), while plasma glucose levels remained unchanged (p=0.348). The control group showed no significant changes in any measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy men aged at least 20 years (n=26).
effective_dosage: 2 g/day of phytosterols and 10 g/day of inulin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological role of phytosterols (PS) in the central nervous system (CNS), both in healthy and diseased states.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the potential of phytosterols to influence cholesterol metabolism in the CNS, suggesting a role in neurological diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS) and Alzheimer's disease (AD), but does not provide specific efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of CNS-related diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plasma Phytosterols (PS) relate to the body's cholesterol synthesis rate and how PS consumption affects plasma cholesterol and lipid profiles.
results_summary: PS treatment significantly reduced plasma total cholesterol, LDL-C, triglycerides, and apo B without affecting HDL-C. The lathosterol-to-cholesterol ratio predicted cholesterol response to PS, with non-responders showing elevated baseline cholesterol synthesis.
population_specificity: 38 non-obese volunteers (58±12 years; LDL-C ≥ 130 mg/dL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of phytosterol particles in stabilizing water-in-oil Pickering emulsions and their potential for controlled-release applications.
results_summary: Phytosterol particles effectively stabilized water-in-oil emulsions, with droplet sizes of 80-100 μm at concentrations of 1.5-3% w/v and water fractions of 0.2-0.6. The study also found that salt release from these emulsions was temperature-dependent, suggesting potential for controlled-release systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the anti-inflammatory effects of phytosterols/stanols and their potential role in atheroprotection and cardiovascular disease prevention.
results_summary: Phytosterols/stanols show beneficial effects on non-lipid variables like inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in experimental studies, but clinical results on inflammatory markers (e.g., CRP, cytokines) are inconsistent. They may serve as adjuncts to statin therapy, but more research is needed.
population_specificity: Populations at low or medium risk of cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and update current knowledge on the molecular mechanisms of phytosterols' anticancer action and their potential in cancer prevention or treatment.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that phytosterols may modulate tumor cell proliferation and apoptosis, supporting their potential anticancer properties, though the exact mechanisms remain under investigation. Few interventional studies have evaluated the efficacy of different types and forms of phytosterols in cancer prevention.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic potential of beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol isolated from Polygonum hydropiper L. against cancer cell lines and their binding affinity to tyrosine kinase enzyme.
results_summary: Beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol demonstrated significant cytotoxicity against HeLa, MCF-7, and NIH/3T3 cell lines, with stigmasterol showing higher efficacy. Docking studies indicated strong binding affinities for both compounds to tyrosine kinase enzyme, suggesting potential anticancer properties.
population_specificity: In vitro cancer cell lines (HeLa, MCF-7, NIH/3T3).
effective_dosage: 1 mg/ml for cytotoxicity assays; IC50 values ranged from 60-440 µg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining phytosterols with curcumin enhances cholesterol-lowering and anti-inflammatory effects compared to phytosterols alone in hypercholesterolaemic individuals.
results_summary: Phytosterols alone significantly reduced total cholesterol (4.8%) and LDL-cholesterol (8.1%), while the combination with curcumin led to even greater reductions (11.0% and 14.4%, respectively). No adverse effects were reported, and HDL-cholesterol and triglycerides remained unchanged across all groups.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolaemic individuals with a mean fasting total cholesterol concentration of 6.57 ± 0.13 mmol/L.
effective_dosage: Phytosterols (2 g/day), curcumin (200 mg/day), or a combination of both.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the relationship between phytosterols and cardiovascular disease risk, focusing on their LDL-cholesterol-lowering effects and potential adverse effects.
results_summary: Phytosterols (2 g/day) significantly reduce LDL-cholesterol levels by 8-10%, but there is no evidence they lower cardiovascular disease risk, and some studies suggest an increased risk of atherosclerosis with higher serum phytosterol levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from typical western diet context).
effective_dosage: 2 g/day of plant sterols and/or stanols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of phytosterols from Diascorea alata on antioxidant activities, plasma lipids, and hematological profiles in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in antioxidant activity (reduced malondialdehyde) and hematological parameters (increased hematocrit and mean corpuscular volume) but no positive effects on lipid profiles after 12 months of treatment.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: Two sachets daily containing 12 mg/dose of Diascorea extracts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effect of phytosterols, red yeast rice, and their combination on lipid profiles in moderately hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: Phytosterols alone (800 mg) showed no significant variation in lipid parameters, while red yeast rice alone significantly reduced LDL-Cholesterol and Apolipoprotein B. The combination of both nutraceuticals resulted in a greater reduction in LDL-Cholesterol and Apolipoprotein B compared to either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Moderately hypercholesterolemic subjects (n=90)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish an efficient ultrasonic-assisted extraction, purification, and crystallization procedure for phytosterols from corn silk.
results_summary: The study achieved a maximum phytosterols recovery of 10.5886 mg/g under optimized conditions (55 min ultrasonic treatment, 12:1 liquid-solid ratio, 35°C, 220 W) and a purity of 92.76% under crystallization conditions (8°C, 12 h, 1:1 solid-liquid ratio).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on corn silk).
study_duration: Not applicable (single extraction and crystallization procedure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if phytosterols cause inflammation in hepatocytes or Kupffer cells independently or require costimulation by LPS.
results_summary: Phytosterols alone did not activate inflammation in hepatocytes or Kupffer cells but synergistically increased interleukin 1β production when combined with LPS. FXR and LXR agonists increased transporter expression in hepatocytes, and GW3965 suppressed proinflammatory cytokine production in Kupffer cells.
population_specificity: Neonatal piglets and their isolated Kupffer cells and hepatocytes.
study_duration: 11 days in vivo, 24-hour incubation in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Phytosterols (PhyS) in milk regulated lipoprotein-associated proteins and inflammatory pathways in overweight healthy volunteers.
results_summary: PhyS-milk intake did not alter lipid-associated plasma proteins but reduced inflammatory molecules (SAP and CCL2), while ω3-milk improved lipid metabolic pathways without affecting the lipid-free plasma proteome.
population_specificity: Thirty-two healthy overweight volunteers (BMI 25-35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify changes in plasma phytosterols and correlate these changes with direct bilirubin levels in children with IFALD after replacing soybean oil with fish oil emulsions.
results_summary: The study found that sitosterol and stigmasterol levels decreased significantly compared to baseline after fish oil treatment, and early changes in stigmasterol were correlated with later changes in direct bilirubin, suggesting a potential role in IFALD treatment response.
population_specificity: Children with intestinal failure-associated liver disease (IFALD), median age 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how phytosterols interact with monoglycerides to structure sunflower oil into oleogels and assess their potential as a pork backfat substitute in frankfurter sausages.
results_summary: Phytosterols combined with monoglycerides strengthened oleogel networks, improving hardness, gel strength, and storage modulus while lowering melting temperatures. When used to replace 50% of pork backfat in sausages, the oleogel-substituted samples showed reduced hardness, brittleness, gumminess, and chewiness but no differences in oxidation levels or overall sensory liking compared to the control.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and food product testing)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a rapid UHPLC-UV/CAD method for the separation and quantitative analysis of seven plant sterols and stanols.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a rapid method for analyzing phytosterols and stanols in 8.5 minutes with high recoveries (95.4%-103.4%) and low relative standard deviations (1.0%-6.7%). Two compounds, campesterol and campestanol, were not separated and were quantified as a sum.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether phytosterols-enriched milk effectively lowers serum LDL-cholesterol in Chinese individuals with a traditional diet high in vegetables and low in meat.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols-enriched milk significantly reduced LDL-cholesterol (9.5%), total cholesterol, and diastolic blood pressure compared to conventional low-fat milk.
population_specificity: 221 Chinese participants (41 men, 180 women; aged 24-79) without cholesterol-lowering drugs or diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g phytosterols per day via enriched low-fat milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immunosuppressive potential of isolated phytosterols (stigmasterol and β-sitosterol) from Clinacanthus nutans leaves on T and B lymphocyte proliferation and cytokine secretion.
results_summary: Stigmasterol (CN2) and β-sitosterol (CN3) inhibited T cell proliferation induced by ConA, but only β-sitosterol blocked Th2 cytokine secretion (IL-4, IL-10) without affecting Th1 cytokines (IL-2, IFN-γ), suggesting selective Th2 suppression and a Th1 bias. β-sitosterol also reduced proliferation of CD4+CD25+ and CD8+CD25+ T cells post-activation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal model implied, but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Phytosterols (PS) on immune response and growth in weaned piglets, comparing it to an antibiotic control.
results_summary: PS supplementation significantly reduced diarrhea rate, improved immune function by shifting towards a Th2 profile, and showed anti-inflammatory effects, with results comparable to polymyxin E. No significant impact on growth or intestinal microorganisms was observed.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (crossbred Duroc × Landrace × Yorkshire) with an average initial weight of 9.58 ± 0.26 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the formation of phytosterol oxidation products (POP) in foods with added phytosterols under various storage and heating conditions.
results_summary: The study found that POP formation in phytosterol-enriched foods is influenced by heating temperature, duration, chemical form of phytosterols, and food matrix, with higher temperatures and longer heating times significantly increasing POP levels. Free plant sterols (FPS) showed higher oxidation rates compared to plant sterol esters (PSE) and plant stanol esters (PAE).
population_specificity: Not specified (review of 14 studies on phytosterol-enriched foods).
effective_dosage: Advised upper daily phytosterol intake of 3 g/d.
study_duration: Not specified (varied heating and storage conditions across studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the toxicity of phytosterols in perilla seed oil-based lipid emulsion (POLE), evaluate the efficacy of phytosterol removal, and confirm the safety of low-phytosterol POLE in dogs.
results_summary: High-phytosterol POLE caused severe adverse effects ("fat overload syndrome") in dogs, including liver injury and metabolic disruption, while low-phytosterol POLE showed no significant toxicity. Phytosterol removal effectively reduced POLE toxicity.
population_specificity: Dogs (n=9)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify selective anti-lung cancer agents from Grewia tiliaefolia, focusing on phytosterols (β-sitosterol and daucosterol), and assess their safety and efficacy in inhibiting lung cancer cell growth.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols from Grewia tiliaefolia effectively inhibited A549 lung cancer cell growth while being non-toxic to normal cells, promoting mitochondrial-dependent apoptosis and arresting the cell cycle at the G2/M phase. Safety was confirmed through non-mutagenic, non-genotoxic, and tolerable profiles in acute and sub-acute toxicity studies.
population_specificity: A549 lung cancer cells, normal human lung L132 cells, and PBMC cells (in vitro); unspecified animal models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dietary combination of wild rice and phytosterols could reduce atherosclerotic lesions and improve cholesterol profiles in LDL-r-KO mice.
results_summary: The combination of wild rice and phytosterols significantly reduced atherosclerotic lesion size and severity, lowered plasma total, LDL, and VLDL cholesterol, and increased fecal cholesterol excretion compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Male LDL receptor knockout (LDL-r-KO) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phytosterol (PS) consumption impacts low-grade inflammation, specifically by assessing inflammatory biomarkers like C-reactive protein (CRP), while also confirming its known LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) lowering effects.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that regular intake of PS-enriched foods did not significantly change CRP levels, but significantly reduced LDL-C concentrations by -14.3 mg/dL. Meta-regression suggested that higher PS doses and longer durations might influence CRP changes, though the overall effect was non-significant.
population_specificity: 1,308 subjects across 20 randomized controlled trials (RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study how fat and phytosterols concentrations affect margarine's behavior under thermo-oxidative conditions.
results_summary: High phytosterol concentrations showed an antioxidant effect, slowing margarine's thermo-oxidation rate and reducing secondary oxidation products. Lower fat concentrations increased thermo-oxidation rates.
population_specificity: Margarine samples (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied concentrations of phytosterols and fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective and anticancer effects of phytosterols, focusing on their mechanisms and potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: Phytosterols were found to improve blood lipid profiles and exhibit protective effects against various cancers, including breast, prostate, lung, liver, stomach, and ovary, by inhibiting cancer cell growth, metastasis, and inducing apoptosis. However, most evidence comes from in vitro and animal studies, with human confirmation still needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (primarily in vitro and animal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of phytosterols and phytostanols in reducing LDL cholesterol and their effects on other lipid parameters.
results_summary: Phytosterols and phytostanols at 2 g/day significantly reduced LDL cholesterol by 8%-10% without affecting HDL cholesterol or lipoprotein (a). They also modestly reduced serum triglycerides in some subjects and decreased atherogenic lipoprotein particles.
population_specificity: Individuals irrespective of age, gender, ethnic background, body weight, or cause of hypercholesterolemia, including those with metabolic syndrome and moderate hypertriglyceridemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pravastatin, phytosterols, and their combination on lipid profiles, specifically LDL cholesterol reduction, in HIV-infected patients with high LDL levels.
results_summary: Phytosterols reduced LDL-c by 9.12%, but this was significantly less effective than pravastatin or combination therapy. The combination of pravastatin and phytosterols did not show additional LDL-c reduction compared to pravastatin alone.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients on ARVs with high LDL cholesterol levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for identifying and quantifying phytosterols in herbal medicinal products and food products, particularly those used for lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: The study successfully identified and quantified ten different sterols, including five Δ(7)-phytosterols, in 31 marketed products using gas chromatography ion trap mass spectrometry. The method was applied to analyze raw materials and finished products.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on product analysis rather than human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary phospholipids and phytosterols have a protective effect against gastroduodenal ulceration, including ulcers caused by NSAIDs.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols (β-sitosterol, stigmasterol) and phospholipids in staple foods from low ulcer prevalence regions were protective against gastric and duodenal ulceration in rat models, promoting ulcer healing and reducing NSAID-induced ulceration.
population_specificity: Rat gastric and duodenal ulcer models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the additional effect of a low-fat phytosterol-enriched fermented milk (PS-FM) on cholesterol metabolism markers and serum lipids in elderly individuals on stable statin therapy with baseline LDL-C <3.35mmol/L.
results_summary: PS-FM consumption led to a significant LDL-C reduction (0.15mmol/L at 3 weeks and 0.27mmol/L at 6 weeks) and increased serum campesterol and sitosterol, reflecting phytosterol intake and inhibition of cholesterol absorption. There was also a reciprocal rise in cholesterol precursors, indicating up-regulation of cholesterol synthesis.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (81±8 years old, 88.6% women, BMI 29.9±6.0kg/m²) living in nursing care facilities on stable statin therapy with baseline LDL-C <3.35mmol/L.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, followed by 6 weeks of washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the removal processes and biotransformation of phytosterols in an aerated stabilization basin (ASB) treatment system fed with pulp and paper wastewater (PPW).
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols are primarily associated with settleable solids in PPW, leading to their accumulation in ASB sediment. Under steady-state conditions, 51% of phytosterols were biotransformed, 40% retained in sediment, and 9% exited with effluent, demonstrating effective removal (82-94%) across varying hydraulic retention times.
population_specificity: Pulp and paper wastewater treatment systems (specifically aerated stabilization basins).
effective_dosage: Total phytosterol loading rates ranged from 10 to 42 μg/L-d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of phytosterols on rumen fermentation in vitro, focusing on gas production, digestibility, microbial protein yield, and volatile fatty acid production.
results_summary: Phytosterols increased gas production, dry matter digestibility, and microbial protein yield while reducing lactate and NH3-N levels. They also elevated volatile fatty acid production, particularly butyrate, suggesting improved rumen fermentation.
population_specificity: In vitro rumen fluid samples
effective_dosage: Various concentrations dissolved in ethyl acetate (8.3%)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ultra-high-pressure homogenization (UHPH) treatments on the extractability of phytosterols in almond beverage compared to the base product.
results_summary: UHPH treatments increased total phytosterol extractability by 20-40%, with the highest extractability observed under the most severe conditions (300 MPa, 75 °C inlet temperature).
population_specificity: Almond beverage (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not available (study focused on processing conditions, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biochemical effects, cardiovascular benefits, efficacy, and safety of phytosterols (PSs) as dietary management for dyslipidemia, including their role as adjunctive therapy to cholesterol-lowering pharmaceuticals.
results_summary: The study found that phytosterols induce clinically relevant reductions in blood LDL cholesterol levels, but there is insufficient evidence regarding their benefits for reducing cardiovascular endpoints or mortality. The review also discusses factors affecting PS efficacy and regulatory aspects.
population_specificity: Individuals with dyslipidemia (general population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if phytosterols (PS) could reduce serum triacylglycerols (TAG) and non-esterified fatty acids (NEFA) and protect against fatty liver development by enhancing bile acid synthesis and improving hepatic gene expression.
results_summary: PS normalized fasting plasma cholesterol, serum TAG, and NEFA concentrations, protected against high-fat diet-induced liver steatosis, and restored hepatic gene expression related to fatty acid oxidation. PS also increased fecal cholesterol excretion and biliary bile acid-to-cholesterol ratio.
population_specificity: Hamsters (Mesocricetus auratus) with diet-induced combined hyperlipidemia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (soybean PS supplemented in high-fat diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of β-cryptoxanthin (β-Cx) and phytosterols (PS) on cardiovascular and bone turnover markers in post-menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that combining β-Cx and PS significantly increased serum levels of β-Cx, β-sitosterol, and campesterol, and led to significant decreases in total cholesterol, c-HDL, c-LDL, and bone turnover markers. The combination showed enhanced cholesterol-lowering effects and potential benefits for osteoporosis risk reduction.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women (n=38)
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/day of PS, administered via a 250 mL milk-based fruit drink
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention with a 4-week washout period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the LDLc-lowering effects of phytosterols (PSRs) and phytostanols (PSNs), both as standalone interventions and as adjuvants to lipid-lowering drugs.
results_summary: The study found that PSRs/PSNs reduce LDLc concentrations by an average of 10%, maintaining efficacy even when combined with lipid-lowering drugs. They are recommended as part of lipid-lowering diets and can serve as adjuvants to drug therapy in some cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with raised LDLc plasma concentration, particularly those with hypercholesterolemia.
interactions: Maintains LDL reduction capacity when administered with lipid-lowering drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of UV-B irradiation on phytosterol concentrations in different types of mushroom powder dietary supplements.
results_summary: The study found that ergosterol concentrations decreased significantly with increased UV-B exposure in most mushroom types, except white mushrooms. Campesterol was also detected but no significant changes were reported.
population_specificity: Mushroom powder dietary supplements (white, brown, oyster, and shiitake mushrooms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the aerobic biotransformation of a phytosterol mixture under different conditions to understand the role of additional carbon sources and solubilizing agents in phytosterol degradation.
results_summary: Phytosterol removal was not significant when added as a powder but occurred when dissolved in ethanol, suggesting bioavailability is limited without a solubilizing agent. The removal rate varied over time, indicating potential involvement of different degradation mechanisms, with β-sitosterol being preferentially degraded.
population_specificity: Mixed culture developed from a pulp and paper wastewater treatment system

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the biotransformation potential of phytosterols (campesterol, stigmasterol, and β-sitosterol) under various anaerobic conditions (denitrifying, sulfate-reducing, and fermentative/methanogenic).
results_summary: Phytosterol removal was observed under nitrate-reducing and sulfate-reducing conditions but not under fermentative/methanogenic conditions. Stigmast-4-en-3-one was identified as an intermediate under sulfate-reducing conditions, suggesting enzymatic biotransformation pathways similar to those reported for cholesterol.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study under controlled conditions).
study_duration: 112 days (16 weekly feeding cycles with a retention time of 21 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cholesterol-lowering effects of phytosterols, both as monotherapy and in combination with statin therapy.
results_summary: Phytosterols reduced cholesterol absorption by about 50%, leading to a 10% reduction in blood cholesterol levels, and may lower LDL-cholesterol, potentially reducing coronary disease risk by 25%. The effect was observed with both phytosterol-enriched foods and supplements.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general population with elevated cholesterol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of phytosterol supplementation on reducing levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) and high-sensitivity CRP (hs-CRP).
results_summary: Phytosterol supplementation did not significantly reduce CRP levels but significantly decreased hs-CRP levels, particularly at doses ≥2000 mg/day.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
